newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Easing ban, Taiwan lets China ships sail strait.
newsitem.headline: Easing ban, Taiwan lets China ships sail strait.

text.p: Taiwan said on Friday it would allow four shipping firms from arch-rival China to sail directly across the Taiwan Strait to the island, cautiously easing a ban dating back to the civil war that split them in 1949.
"They can start whenever they are ready," Teng You-yi, a senior official at Taiwan's southern Kaohsiung port, told Reuters by telephone after signing the approvals.

The move eliminates the final hurdle to the first direct sailings of the Taiwan Strait in 48 years, although Nationalist Taiwan -- deeply wary of communist China -- has put restrictions in place forbidding direct cargo exchanges.
"We should not fall into communist China's trap and believe that this is direct links," said Kao Koong-lien, vice chairman of the cabinet's policy-making Mainland Affairs Council.
"What we will conduct is offshore transshipments," Kao said. "It's clearly not direct links because (mainland) cargoes will not be able to enter our customs and will not enter Taiwan."

Taipei has banned direct contacts with the mainland since the Nationalist Republic of China, defeated by the communists in 1949, fled into exile on Taiwan. Beijing regards Taiwan as a rebel-held province that must be brought under its sovereignty.

Taiwan will allow approved vessels to sail directly into Kaohsiung from China's ports at Xiamen or Fuzhou, but insists their cargoes be shipped onward to third countries -- refusing entry to Taiwan customs to uphold the ban on direct contacts.
Likewise, Taiwan cargoes at Kaohsiung cannot be put directly aboard vessels that will cross to Xiamen or Fuzhou.

There was no word from Beijing about applications submitted by a dozen Taiwan shipping firms eager to ply the long-forbidden routes. China has said it was reviewing the requests and would act on them promptly.
Kao urged Beijing to issue approvals swiftly, saying Taipei had acted in good faith and hoped for further developments.

"This shows our government's good will and sincerity, but it takes effort by both sides," Kao said. "By doing offshore transshipments we hope both sides can find common interest and cultivate mutual trust. Then we can prepare for direct links."

Some 30,000 Taiwan firms cultivating US$30 billion in "indirect" mainland investments have pressed Taipei to ease its ban, saying direct sea, air and other links would pare away the extra costs of routing business through Hong Kong.
Spokesman M.S. Tsay of container giant Yangming Marine Transport Co, one of Taiwan's direct-links hopefuls, hailed the breakthrough and urged Beijing to reciprocate.
"We are waiting for movement by the mainland," Tsay said.
Yangming and other Taiwan shippers say they expect to profit from the new routes despite the cargo restrictions.

Taiwan approved weekly or twice-weekly routes by one ship each from state-owned mainland firms Fujian Foreign Trade Centre Shipping Co, Fujian Provincial Shipping Co, Fujian Xiamen Shipping Co and Shamen Ocean Shipping Co, officials said.

Two of the mainland ships fly Panamanian flags, while two are registered in Saint Vincent. Taiwan bars vessels flying communist China's red five-starred flag, while those flying Taiwan's Republic of China flag are unwelcome in mainland ports.
Both sides have said they would allow Hong Kong-flagged ships to make the crossings.
